title: Bianca Spender shakes off her famous mother's shadow
text:
Clare Press Sustainable Style Columnist Aug 30, 2019 — 12.11pm Share

What do you think about birds?” asks fashion designer Bianca Spender. We’re in her new studio in Sydney’s Rushcutters Bay – after years of sharing commercial premises in town with her mother, Carla Zampatti, Spender moved in January. The new digs are a bijou jewel with harbour glimpses, i.e. tiny, but she’s delighted to be crammed in here with her small team.

She proffers a dog-eared copy of The Field Guide to the Birds of Australia. “I’ve spent the last week identifying birds for the boys.” Sons Dominic and Florian are 7 and 10. “It occurred to us that birds are very fashion. I mean, look at cockatoos with their punk yellow hair.”

Like a bird, she flies between topics. Although she says she wants to slow down, the Bianca Spender I know is often in a hurry. I once went to the theatre with her and afterwards we walked to the train together. As she zoomed off up the street, I had to jog. I rack my brains trying to think which bird she’s most like. Then it hits me. Of course. She is a rare bird.

“The craft of making clothes, the fashion business, cutting, sewing – that’s my heritage”: Bianca Spender. James Brickwood

In May, just days before Australian Fashion Week, Spender presented her 10th anniversary collection not on a runway but at her home in Bronte, to a hand-picked list of 80 interesting women – not 450 bloggers, buyers and journalists, which she’d done the year before. Glossy-magazine editors mingled with creatives Spender has worked with over the years and who have become close friends: sculptor Anna-Wili Highfield, curator Nina Miall, filmmaker Jasmin Tarasin.

As the models walked through the crowd, Spender described her creative process, white skin gleaming in the darkness, hand-talking (she’s half Italian) in her one-shouldered black dress. She mentioned the naive art movement and Depression-era craft – juxtaposed make-do-and-mend with the sophistication of couture techniques – and explained how these things had inspired the collection. She talked about how important it is for clothes to move with the body. Linking the women in the room with the women who make her clothes, she riffed on her respect for them all.

The point of the evening was not to drum up press or even capture the activity. “Think of a dinner party with amazing conversations. Do you take photos? No. It will be embedded in your memory, because you were present. When I did the collab with Raf, he told me: ‘The dance only rests in the body of the dancers and the people who watched it.’ It’s ephemeral.”

Raf is Rafael Bonachela, artistic director of the Sydney Dance Company. Spender worked with him on Cinco, which premiered in April. She designed costumes for the second of this production’s three acts, using wisps of lemon yellow georgette. She wore some herself to take her bow with the company when the curtain closed.

Spender has “a genuine love for and understanding of the arts”, says Bonachela. “She clothed the dancers in fluid twists and falls to match their physical grace. I knew that Bianca’s refined aesthetic could embody the spirit of the work.”

I was at Cinco’s opening night with a coterie of Spenderites, clad in her tuxedo jackets and devoré dresses. Her friends are her customers.
description: After almost 10 years of flying solo in the fashion business, Carla Zampatti's daughter has emerged as one of Australia's leading design talents.
